awd_titl_txt: Molecular mechanisms of the sense of touch
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to sense the world though physical contact is essential for all living organisms. The sense of touch is essential for navigation in the environment, object recognition, detection of pain and pleasure. It facilitates the establishment of maternal bonds and underlies the development of social behaviors. The sense of touch includes the sense of physical contact and temperature, but the mechanism is poorly understood. This project seeks to reveal molecular principles underlying the detection of physical touch, and understand how temperature influences this process. These studies will use tactile foraging ducks that allow examination of these general physiological problems through the perspective of a tactile specialist animal. This research will provide mechanistic insights into the process of touch detection and reveal general principles of mechanosensitivity in vertebrates. The broader impact activities aim to promote science among school students, with a focus on ethnic and socioeconomic groups underrepresented among scientists. The PI will reach out to schools in CT, MA and NY to teach how people feel touch, warmth and cold, how they see, smell or taste. Most of the trainees are female, underrepresented minorities, economically disadvantaged, or from families without prior college graduates. The activities are designed and implemented by undergraduates, PhD students and postdocs from the lab, under close supervision of the principal investigator. This approach provides a unique teaching experience to our lab members and help them advance professionally to become educator-researchers.

In many vertebrates, fine tactile tasks are accomplished by organs covered with glabrous skin, such as the palm of hand in primates, or the bill of tactile foraging ducks. These organs specialize in the detection of the lightest forms of touch, such as transient contact and vibration, via mechanosensory corpuscles. How corpuscles convert touch into electrical signaling, what molecules are involved and how they work, remains largely unknown. The investigators will approach this problem by studying mechanosensitivity in the bill of tactile specialist ducks. They showed that duck bill contains numerous lamellar corpuscles innervated by trigeminal mechanoreceptors. Here, the investigator proposes to use the duck model to reveal general principles of touch detection by neuronal and non-neuronal components of mechanosensory corpuscles. This project aims to: (1) Determine the molecular basis of tactile-thermal interaction in neuronal mechanoreceptors. Mild cooling potentiates tactile acuity in vertebrates, but the mechanism is unknown. This project will test the hypothesis that cooling increases the ability of neuronal mechanoreceptors to convert touch into excitation, and identify the molecular basis of this process. (2) Investigate whether lamellar cells from Herbst (Pacinian) corpuscles can detect touch. It is well established that lamellar cells form a cushion around the neuronal core, acting as a passive mechanical filter. The investigator aims to test the hypothesis that lamellar cells are also mechanically sensitive, and are able to convert touch into excitation, actively contributing to the detection of touch.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The sense of touch, or mechanosensitivity, is an indispensable sense possessed by all vertebrates without exception, including humans. It allows us to interact with the physical world, navigate in the environment, establish maternal bonds, detect affective and pleasant touch, it warns us of mechanical damage, it informs us taking care of a wounded limb, and helps us sense our body position through the feeling of muscle tension and joint angle. Although losing sight, hearing, olfaction or taste creates enormous difficulties for our day-to-day life, losing the sense of touch is simply unimaginable. Indeed, it is difficult to even comprehend what it is like not to be able to sense the world that surround us. Without the sense of touch, we wouldn’t even be able to hold an object in our hand. And yet, compared to the other senses, the sense of touch remains the least well understood at the cellular and molecular levels. The overarching question of this proposal is to obtain a deep mechanistic understanding of how vertebrates detect touch.

The skin if vertebrates contains different types of mechanoreceptor end-organs, including Merkel cell-neurite complexes, Meissner and Pacinian corpuscles. Of these, Pacinian corpuscles play the vital role of detecting transient touch and vibration. They are present in the skin covering the palm of our hand, where they supply tactile information that allows us to hold and manipulate objects. In this proposal, we sought to understand general mechanistic principles of how Pacinian corpuscles detect touch.

To achieve our goal, we looked at the general problem of Pacinian corpuscle function from the perspective of a tactile specialist animal—Pekin duck (Anas platyrhynchos domesticus), one the most sophisticated tactile foragers among vertebrates. The skin covering duck bill contains numerouos Pacinian corpuscles accessible to experimental manipulations. This approach provides an innovative viewpoint on this universal physiological phenomenon from a standpoint unachievable using the standard rodent models alone.

There are several major scientific outcomes of this proposal. First, we established Pekin duck as a versatile laboratory model to study mechanosensitivity of Pacinian corpuscles. We have developed experimental approaches that allowed us to interrogate the cellular and molecular basis of touch detection in these structures in close-to-physiological conditions. Pacinian corpuscles have a highly complex architecture. They are covered by a multilayered onion-like structure, called the outer core, which encompasses the sensory inner core composed of Schwann cell-derived lamellar cells with the mechanoreceptor afferent ending in its center. Second, we used focused ion beam scanning electron microscopy to obtain the first 3D structure of an entire Pacinian corpuscle which shows the spatial arrangement of the different corpuscular components at high resolution. This result provides a structural basis for understanding the contribution of the corpuscular components to touch detection. Third, we uncovered the mechanism of thermal-tactile integration in the corpuscles whereby cold temperature potentiates mechanosensory acuity. We found that this process depends on the biophysical properties of mechanically gated ion channels in the nerve terminal. When cooled down, these ion channels become hyper-active, facilitating the probability of nerve signal generation. This finding provides mechanistic insights into thermal-tactile interaction in mechanoreceptors, and lays foundation for future studies of the sensory crosstalk in the peripheral nervous system. Fourth, we discovered that the outer core cells that form the multilayered capsule around Pacinian corpuscles are mechanosensitive. These experiments revealed a novel role for the lamellar cells as active mechanosensors that likely participate in the detection of touch. Together, our findings supplied deep structural and functional insights into the mechanism of Pacinian corpuscles, which will be used by us and others in the future to elucidate the process of touch detection in these essential end-organs. Our studies were published in several peer-reviewed open-access research journals, including eLife, Science Advances and others, presented at numerous conferences and university departments in the US and internationally.

We believe it is our duty as academicians to not only obtain knowledge, but also to disseminate it, especially among children, who are the scientists of tomorrow. Therefore, for our studies to have a broader impact on the society, we organized the Sensory Physiology Club, an extracurricular initiative aimed to promote science among students of different ages. Sensory Physiology Club’s program includes in-class and online sessions, each containing a series of lectures and experiments. We explore the sense of temperature, touch, taste, olfaction, and vision using both textbook-grade knowledge, and our own experimental data. Our experiments and lectures go beyond the standard teaching curricula of most schools. We actively reach out to students of ethnic, economic, and social backgrounds traditionally underrepresented in science. Over 50% of our trainees are female, black, Hispanic, or from families without college graduates or with poor income. During the duration of this proposal, we trained over 400 students, largely from public schools serving economically disadvantaged areas of Connecticut, New York and Massachusetts schools.
